TRACK TEAM HOLDS FIRST
PRACTICE
Last Tuesday the Track Team
held its first practice of the season. The purpose of early practice
is to condition the men for spring
work.
Manager Kirwan distributed
equipment to the candidates;
lockers were also assigned. Jumping standards, hurdles, weights,
javelins and pole vaulting sticks
were brought into shape.
Captain Aaronson and Coach
La Cato were very much pleased
with the showing that the new
men made in their initial practice.
The work-outs during the early
part of the year will be devoted
mainly to loosening up . tight
muscles. Assistant Manager Hamburger rigged up a punching bag
outside of the athletic dressing
rooms for the purpose of instructing the track men in its use.
During the early part of the
year practice will be held only
Tuesdays and Fridays. Candidates are urged to report to the
manager at the field .

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 24, 1922.
SIX CONTESTS FOR SYRACUSE TWELVE
Arrange Lacrosse Schedule for
Visit to England
Syracuse, N. Y.—Word has
been received by Coach Laurie
Cox, of the Orange lacrosse forces,
to the effect that the schedule to
be played on Syracuse's 1922 invasion of the British Isles is rapidly nearing completion. The Oxford-Cambridge authorities in
charge of arrangements have announced that six games have been
booked and more are likely to be
added.
Some difficulty is being had in
booking games in England due to
the time that the Orange squad
will make their trip,-which will be
late in June, when; most of the
athletic clubs and schools in
England have dropped lacrosse
and are devoting their time to
cricket. Therefore the schedule will be shorter than that
Of the Oxford-Cambridge team
when they came to this country
early last spring. At that time
the lacrosse season here was at its
height.
It was at first hoped that the
American team could make the
trip at Easter time, but this was
found to be impossible owing to
the interference of studies. This
plan would also interfere with the
regular schedule of games to be
played among the colleges in the
spring, and Syracuse with a veteran aggregation to put on the
field has hopes of again claiming
the championship. A trip to England at Easter time would necessitate the withdrawal of the Orange
team from the northern division
of the Intercollegiate League.
With the foreign trip in view,
the spring schedule this year will
probably be kept down to about
eight or nine games. Manager
Folsom is already at work arranging suitable dates with the various managements. Four league
games will be played as usual with
Cornell, Hobart, Yale and Harvard. The latter two teams will
be met on the Syracuse field this
season. The remaining games of
the schedule will no doubt include
games with the Navy, Penn State,
Crescent A. C. and the local lacrosse club.
Coach Cox is holding a sixweeks' practice session this fall
to keep his men in condition and
also to look over the possible material eligible from last year's
Freshman squad. About forty candidates are reporting for these
workouts and competition is keen
for the various positions on the
team left vacant by the graduation
of Captain Lydecker and Paul

Engineering for the Buyer
It is not enough that electrical apparatus
should be carefully conceived, skillfully
designed, and exactingly manufactured.
Engineering, to fulfill all its functions,
must go beyond these necessary steps and
do a still more enlightened service. It
must apply the apparatus to its uses, so
that not only in design and construction
but in service as well, all the conditions
that must be reckoned with are fully
satisfied.
This function of Westinghouse application engineering covers many fields, and
charges itself with many responsibilities.
It is engineering that concerns itself with
almost every aspect of business, central
station, transportation, industrial, mining, electro-chemical, etc. It has the
buyer's interest constantly at heart.
Westinghouse Application Engineering
works with salesmen, with buyers, with
consulting engineers, with contractors,
and with service and repair men; it finds
and investigates new fields; it checks the

behavior of apparatus, old and new; it is a
bridge over which information passes
freely in both directions between Westinghouse and its thousands of clients and
friends.
Be glad that you are to live and work
in times when the spirit of service dominates commercial operations. The greatest change that has occurred in business
in the last few decades has been in the
minds of men. No longer need the buyer
beware for it is now known that the
seller's obligation reaches beyond the
completion of the sale; and that it is
both wise and right that every reasonable
effort be made to give the buyer full
value in both product and satisfaction.
The practise of this policy requires engineering of the highest type in research,
design, manufacturing and every other
phase of Westinghouse operations, but
nowhere to greater degree than in the
field of application engineering, which is
essentially engineering for the buyer.

TRACK TEAM HOLDS FIRST
PRACTICE
Last Tuesday the Track Team
held its first practice of the season. The purpose of early practice
is to condition the men for spring
work.
Manager Kirwan distributed
equipment to the candidates;
lockers were also assigned. Jumping standards, hurdles, weights,
javelins and pole vaulting sticks
were brought into shape.
Captain Aaronson and Coach
La Cato were very much pleased
with the showing that the new
men made in their initial practice.
The work-outs during the early
part of the year will be devoted
mainly to loosening up . tight
muscles. Assistant Manager Hamburger rigged up a punching bag
outside of the athletic dressing
rooms for the purpose of instructing the track men in its use.
During the early part of the
year practice will be held only
Tuesdays and Fridays. Candidates are urged to report to the
manager at the field .

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 24, 1922.
SIX CONTESTS FOR SYRACUSE TWELVE
Arrange Lacrosse Schedule for
Visit to England
Syracuse, N. Y.—Word has
been received by Coach Laurie
Cox, of the Orange lacrosse forces,
to the effect that the schedule to
be played on Syracuse's 1922 invasion of the British Isles is rapidly nearing completion. The Oxford-Cambridge authorities in
charge of arrangements have announced that six games have been
booked and more are likely to be
added.
Some difficulty is being had in
booking games in England due to
the time that the Orange squad
will make their trip,-which will be
late in June, when; most of the
athletic clubs and schools in
England have dropped lacrosse
and are devoting their time to
cricket. Therefore the schedule will be shorter than that
Of the Oxford-Cambridge team
when they came to this country
early last spring. At that time
the lacrosse season here was at its
height.
It was at first hoped that the
American team could make the
trip at Easter time, but this was
found to be impossible owing to
the interference of studies. This
plan would also interfere with the
regular schedule of games to be
played among the colleges in the
spring, and Syracuse with a veteran aggregation to put on the
field has hopes of again claiming
the championship. A trip to England at Easter time would necessitate the withdrawal of the Orange
team from the northern division
of the Intercollegiate League.
With the foreign trip in view,
the spring schedule this year will
probably be kept down to about
eight or nine games. Manager
Folsom is already at work arranging suitable dates with the various managements. Four league
games will be played as usual with
Cornell, Hobart, Yale and Harvard. The latter two teams will
be met on the Syracuse field this
season. The remaining games of
the schedule will no doubt include
games with the Navy, Penn State,
Crescent A. C. and the local lacrosse club.
Coach Cox is holding a sixweeks' practice session this fall
to keep his men in condition and
also to look over the possible material eligible from last year's
Freshman squad. About forty candidates are reporting for these
workouts and competition is keen
for the various positions on the
team left vacant by the graduation
of Captain Lydecker and Paul
Lowry, star defense men. Many
of the men now reporting will
keep in condition during the winter in other lines of sport and will
report early in the spring.

Engineering for the Buyer
It is not enough that electrical apparatus
should be carefully conceived, skillfully
designed, and exactingly manufactured.
Engineering, to fulfill all its functions,
must go beyond these necessary steps and
do a still more enlightened service. It
must apply the apparatus to its uses, so
that not only in design and construction
but in service as well, all the conditions
that must be reckoned with are fully
satisfied.
This function of Westinghouse application engineering covers many fields, and
charges itself with many responsibilities.
It is engineering that concerns itself with
almost every aspect of business, central
station, transportation, industrial, mining, electro-chemical, etc. It has the
buyer's interest constantly at heart.
Westinghouse Application Engineering
works with salesmen, with buyers, with
consulting engineers, with contractors,
and with service and repair men; it finds
and investigates new fields; it checks the

behavior of apparatus, old and new; it is a
bridge over which information passes
freely in both directions between Westinghouse and its thousands of clients and
friends.
Be glad that you are to live and work
in times when the spirit of service dominates commercial operations. The greatest change that has occurred in business
in the last few decades has been in the
minds of men. No longer need the buyer
beware for it is now known that the
seller's obligation reaches beyond the
completion of the sale; and that it is
both wise and right that every reasonable
effort be made to give the buyer full
value in both product and satisfaction.
The practise of this policy requires engineering of the highest type in research,
design, manufacturing and every other
phase of Westinghouse operations, but
nowhere to greater degree than in the
field of application engineering, which is
essentially engineering for the buyer.
